issues.title: Using `delegatecall` in loop
issues.description: When calling `delegatecall` the same `msg.value` amount will be accredited multiple times.

issues.title: `abi.encodePacked()` should not be used with dynamic types when passing the result to a hash function such as `keccak256()`
issues.description:
Use `abi.encode()` instead which will pad items to 32 bytes, which will [prevent hash collisions](https://docs.soliditylang.org/en/v0.8.13/abi-spec.html#non-standard-packed-mode) (e.g. `abi.encodePacked(0x123,0x456)` => `0x123456` => `abi.encodePacked(0x1,0x23456)`, but `abi.encode(0x123,0x456)` => `0x0...1230...456`). Unless there is a compelling reason, `abi.encode` should be preferred. If there is only one argument to `abi.encodePacked()` it can often be cast to `bytes()` or `bytes32()` [instead](https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/30912/how-to-compare-strings-in-solidity#answer-82739).
If all arguments are strings and or bytes, `bytes.concat()` should be used instead.

issues.title: Using `block.timestamp` for swap deadline offers no protection
issues.description: In the PoS model, proposers know well in advance if they will propose one or consecutive blocks ahead of time. In such a scenario, a malicious validator can hold back the transaction and execute it at a more favourable block number.Consider allowing function caller to specify swap deadline input parameter.

issues.title: Arbitrary `from` passed to `transferFrom` (or `safeTransferFrom`)
issues.description: Passing an arbitrary `from` address to `transferFrom` (or `safeTransferFrom`) can lead to loss of funds, because anyone can transfer tokens from the `from` address if an approval is made.

issues.title: Unprotected initializer
issues.description: Consider protecting the initializer functions with modifiers.

issues.title: Unsafe Casting
issues.description: Downcasting int/uints in Solidity can be unsafe due to the potential for data loss and unintended behavior.When downcasting a larger integer type to a smaller one (e.g., uint256 to uint128), the value may exceed the range of the target type,leading to truncation and loss of significant digits. Use OpenZeppelin's SafeCast library to safely downcast integers.

issues.title: EnumerableSet.remove in loop corrupts the set order.
issues.description:
If the order of an EnumerableSet is required, removing items in a loop using `at` and `remove` corrupts this order.
Consider using a different data structure or removing items by collecting them during the loop, then removing after the loop.

issues.title: Experimental ABI Encoder
issues.description: Experimental encoders should not be used in production. There are multiple known compiler bugs that are caused by the experimental encoder. Upgrade your solidity version to remove the need for experimental features.

issues.title: Incorrect Assembly Shift Parameter Order
issues.description: Example: `shl(shifted, 4)` will shift the right constant `4` by `a` bits. The correct order is `shl(4, shifted)`.

issues.title: Storage Array Edited with Memory
issues.description: Storage reference is passed to a function with a memory parameter. This will not update the storage variable as expected. Consider using storage parameters instead.

issues.title: Contract Has Multiple Constructors
issues.description: In some versions of Solidity, contracts compile with multiple constructors. The first constructor takes precedence. This can lead to unexpected behavior.

issues.title: Contract Name Reused in Different Files
issues.description: When compiling contracts with certain development frameworks (for example: Truffle), having contracts with the same name across different files can lead to one being overwritten.

issues.title: Nested Structs in Mappings pre-0.5.0
issues.description: Prior to updates in Solidity 0.5.0, public mappings with nested structs compiled, but produced incorrect values. Refrain from using these, or update to a more recent version of Solidity.

issues.title: Depracated EVM Instruction for `selfdestruct` should not be used.
Array length value has a direct assignment.
issues.description: If the length of a dynamic array (storage variable) directly assigned to, it may allow access to other storage slots by tweaking it's value. This practice has been depracated in newer Solidity versions

issues.title: Uninitialized State Variables
issues.description: Solidity does initialize variables by default when you declare them, however it's good practice to explicitly declare an initial value. For example, if you transfer money to an address we must make sure that the address has been initialized.

issues.title: Incorrect use of caret operator on a non hexadcimal constant
issues.description: The caret operator is usually mistakenly thought of as an exponentiation operator but actually, it's a bitwise xor operator.

issues.title: Yul block contains `return` function call.
issues.description: Remove this, as this causes execution to halt. Nothing after that call will execute, including code following the assembly block.

issues.title: High Issue Title
issues.description: Description of the high issue.

issues.title: Unchecked `bool success` value for send call.
issues.description: The transaction `address(payable?).send(address)` may fail because of reasons like out-of-gas, invalid receipient address or revert from the recipient. Therefore, the boolean returned by this function call must be checked to be `true` in order to verify that the transaction was successful

issues.title: Misused boolean with logical operators
issues.description: The patterns `if (… || true)` and `if (.. && false)` will always evaluate to true and false respectively.

issues.title: Sending native Eth is not protected from these functions.
issues.description: Introduce checks for `msg.sender` in the function

issues.title: Delegatecall made by the function without checks on any adress.
issues.description: Introduce checks on the address

issues.title: Tautological comparison.
issues.description: The left hand side and the right hand side of the binary operation has the same value. This makes the condition always true or always false.

issues.title: RTLO character detected in file. \u{202e}
issues.description: Right to left override character may be misledaing and cause potential attacks by visually misordering method arguments!

issues.title: Return value of the function call is not checked.
issues.description: Function returns a value but it is ignored.

issues.title: Dangerous unary operator found in assignment.
issues.description: Potentially mistakened `=+` for `+=` or `=-` for `-=`. Please include a space in between.

issues.title: Weak Randomness
issues.description: The use of keccak256 hash functions on predictable values like block.timestamp, block.number, or similar data, including modulo operations on these values, should be avoided for generating randomness, as they are easily predictable and manipulable. The `PREVRANDAO` opcode also should not be used as a source of randomness. Instead, utilize Chainlink VRF for cryptographically secure and provably random values to ensure protocol integrity.

issues.title: Usage of variable before declaration.
issues.description: This is a bad practice that may lead to unintended consequences. Please declare the variable before using it.

issues.title: Deletion from a nested mappping.
issues.description: A deletion in a structure containing a mapping will not delete the mapping. The remaining data may be used to compromise the contract.

issues.title: Centralization Risk for trusted owners
issues.description: Contracts have owners with privileged rights to perform admin tasks and need to be trusted to not perform malicious updates or drain funds.

issues.title: Solmate's SafeTransferLib does not check for token contract's existence
issues.description:
There is a subtle difference between the implementation of solmate's SafeTransferLib and OZ's SafeERC20: OZ's SafeERC20 checks if the token is a contract or not, solmate's SafeTransferLib does not.
https://github.com/transmissions11/solmate/blob/main/src/utils/SafeTransferLib.sol#L9 
`@dev Note that none of the functions in this library check that a token has code at all! That responsibility is delegated to the caller`

issues.title: `ecrecover` is susceptible to signature malleability
issues.description: The `ecrecover` function is susceptible to signature malleability. This means that the same message can be signed in multiple ways, allowing an attacker to change the message signature without invalidating it. This can lead to unexpected behavior in smart contracts, such as the loss of funds or the ability to bypass access control. Consider using OpenZeppelin's ECDSA library instead of the built-in function.

issues.title: Deprecated OpenZeppelin functions should not be used
issues.description: Openzeppelin has deprecated several functions and replaced with newer versions. Please consult https://docs.openzeppelin.com/

issues.title: Unsafe ERC20 Operations should not be used
issues.description: ERC20 functions may not behave as expected. For example: return values are not always meaningful. It is recommended to use OpenZeppelin's SafeERC20 library.

issues.title: Solidity pragma should be specific, not wide
issues.description: Consider using a specific version of Solidity in your contracts instead of a wide version. For example, instead of `pragma solidity ^0.8.0;`, use `pragma solidity 0.8.0;`

issues.title: Missing checks for `address(0)` when assigning values to address state variables
issues.description: Check for `address(0)` when assigning values to address state variables.

issues.title: `public` functions not used internally could be marked `external`
issues.description: Instead of marking a function as `public`, consider marking it as `external` if it is not used internally.

issues.title: Define and use `constant` variables instead of using literals
issues.description: If the same constant literal value is used multiple times, create a constant state variable and reference it throughout the contract.

issues.title: Event is missing `indexed` fields
issues.description: Index event fields make the field more quickly accessible to off-chain tools that parse events. However, note that each index field costs extra gas during emission, so it's not necessarily best to index the maximum allowed per event (three fields). Each event should use three indexed fields if there are three or more fields, and gas usage is not particularly of concern for the events in question. If there are fewer than three fields, all of the fields should be indexed.

issues.title: Empty `require()` / `revert()` statements
issues.description: Use descriptive reason strings or custom errors for revert paths.

issues.title: The `nonReentrant` `modifier` should occur before all other modifiers
issues.description: This is a best-practice to protect against reentrancy in other modifiers.

issues.title: Using `ERC721::_mint()` can be dangerous
issues.description: Using `ERC721::_mint()` can mint ERC721 tokens to addresses which don't support ERC721 tokens. Use `_safeMint()` instead of `_mint()` for ERC721.

issues.title: PUSH0 is not supported by all chains
issues.description: Solc compiler version 0.8.20 switches the default target EVM version to Shanghai, which means that the generated bytecode will include PUSH0 opcodes. Be sure to select the appropriate EVM version in case you intend to deploy on a chain other than mainnet like L2 chains that may not support PUSH0, otherwise deployment of your contracts will fail.

issues.title: Modifiers invoked only once can be shoe-horned into the function
Empty Block
issues.description: Consider removing empty blocks.

issues.title: Large literal values multiples of 10000 can be replaced with scientific notation
issues.description: Use `e` notation, for example: `1e18`, instead of its full numeric value.

issues.title: Internal functions called only once can be inlined
issues.description: Instead of separating the logic into a separate function, consider inlining the logic into the calling function. This can reduce the number of function calls and improve readability.

issues.title: Contract still has TODOs
issues.description: Contract contains comments with TODOS

issues.title: Inconsistency in declaring uint256/uint (or) int256/int variables within a contract. Use explicit size declarations (uint256 or int256).
issues.description: Consider keeping the naming convention consistent in a given contract. Explicit size declarations are preferred (uint256, int256) over implicit ones (uint, int) to avoid confusion.

issues.title: Unused Custom Error
issues.description: it is recommended that the definition be removed when custom error is unused

issues.title: Loop contains `require`/`revert` statements
issues.description: Avoid `require` / `revert` statements in a loop because a single bad item can cause the whole transaction to fail. It's better to forgive on fail and return failed elements post processing of the loop

issues.title: Incorrect Order of Division and Multiplication
issues.description: Division operations followed directly by multiplication operations can lead to precision loss due to the way integer arithmetic is handled in Solidity.

issues.title: Redundant statements have no effect.
issues.description: Remove the redundant statements because no code will be generated and it just congests the codebase.

issues.title: Public variables of a contract read in an external context (using `this`).
issues.description: The contract reads it's own variable using `this` which adds an unnecessary STATICCALL. Remove `this` and access the variable like storage.
